# Day 685

![](https://miro.medium.com/0*40chDoyXR98xTrCf)

<iframe src="https://cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?type=text%2Fhtml&key=a19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07&schema=twitter&url=https%3A//twitter.com/ConorChepenik/status/1754684971808104801%3Fs%3D20&image=" title="" height="281" width="500"></iframe>

1. The Power of Appearances: Everyone sees what you appear to be, few experience what you really are. Cultivate a strong public image; perceptions often matter more than reality in politics.

2. The Necessity of Adaptability: One must be a fox to recognize traps, and a lion to frighten wolves. Be adaptable and ready to change tactics as circumstances evolve.

3. The Importance of Being Feared: It is better to be feared than loved, if you cannot be both. Commanding respect (and sometimes fear) can be more reliable than seeking to be liked.

4. The Use of Cruelty: Since being loved and hated are both dangerous, a prince should rely on what is in his power and not on what is in the power of others. A ruler should not shy away from using cruelty if it ensures power and control.

5. The Role of Fortune and Virtue: Fortune is the arbiter of one-half of our actions, but she still leaves us to direct the other half. Luck plays a role, but a savvy political actor can and must still steer their own course.

6. The Strength of the Lion and the Shrewdness of the Fox: A prince, therefore, being compelled knowingly to adopt the beast, ought to choose the fox and the lion; for the lion cannot defend himself against snares and the fox cannot defend himself against wolves. Be strong but also cunning; power is maintained by a combination of force and cleverness.

7. The Danger of Half Measures: He who does not lay his foundations beforehand may by great ability do so afterwards, but with great trouble to the architect and danger to the building. Commit fully to your actions; indecision or half measures can lead to failure.

The Prince provides pragmatic advice for obtaining and maintaining political power. While many readers recoil at suggestions of cruelty, deception, and manipulation, Machiavelli aimed not to moralize but to analyze realistically how power is gained and preserved.

Ultimately, the end goal for Machiavelli was political stability and security of the state, even if the means seem ethically dubious today. The Prince is not a guide for how one should live virtuously, but a clinical examination of the tools and tactics that have historically proved effective in the "game" of politics.

Regardless of you moral compass, one should not ignore the realities Machiavelli exposes about holding power. His advice remains startlingly relevant for those entering the political arena or seeking to understand the levers of control in government and society.

While the methods may be concerning, the enduring fascination with The Prince stems from Machiavelli's direct, unflinching look at the relationship between morality and power - tensions which remain very much alive nearly 500 years later. I'll close this Medium by echoing Machiavelli's timeless recognition: fortune is ever-changing, only virtuous principles stand firm.

2/5/24

Conor Jay Chepenik
